awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Conference: NSF Workshop Sustainable Computing for Sustainability
awd_abstract_narration:
The motivations behind this project are two-fold.  It is driven by the growing role of computing as an essential tool in devising solutions to the many major societal problems created by climate change.  At the same time, it is an acknowledgment of the fact that, in spite of its positive role, computing is itself facing sustainability challenges as well as contributing to some of the factors behind climate change.  Fostering the development of new initiatives addressing those problems and challenges is the main goal of this project. The project’s novelties lie in jointly addressing the dual role of computing as an enabler of solutions to climate change as well as a contributor to climate change itself, and in exploring the challenges faced by the interdisciplinary teams needed to develop effective approaches.  The project’s impacts are similarly two-fold:  It will help prioritize new research directions where computing can have a transformative role in developing solutions to climate change challenges and it will increase awareness of the need for computing to account for sustainability in its own development.

Towards realizing the project’s goals, the investigators rely on a two-prong approach.  The project’s first phase consists of an open information gathering effort conducted virtually (online) towards identifying critical, yet poorly explored sustainability problems that computing can help address. The second phase seeks to develop a concrete agenda for not only addressing those challenges, but equally importantly help build and sustain the interdisciplinary scientific community that successfully tackling them requires.  This second phase is in the form of a workshop bringing together not only researchers across the required disciplines, but also researchers with expertise in building interdisciplinary teams and team science towards informing the creation and sustainability of successful teams involving participants across multiple disciplines.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The focus of the project was the organization of a workshop on “Sustainable Computing for Sustainability.”   The workshop’s goals were to (i) advance the development of research initiatives along the themes of both “sustainable computing” and “computing for sustainability”, while also (ii) helping develop guidance on how to sustain the interdisciplinary teams those initiatives would need.  

Sustainable computing targets making computing itself more sustainable, e.g., by lowering the energy consumption of data centers that have become major consumers of electricity.  Conversely, computing for sustainability seeks to leverage the power of computing to help study and hopefully mitigate the many sustainability challenges we currently face, e.g., develop better and more accurate climate models or improve crop yields by monitoring soil composition and adjusting watering, fertilization, and application of pesticides in real-time.  

Common to both sustainable computing and computing for sustainability is the fact that (effective) solutions call for combining expertise and perspectives from multiple disciplines.  This is certainly true for the “technical” side of the problems, e.g., developing solutions that adjust crop watering in real-time requires a combination of software and hardware skills, as well as knowledge of crop science. But it extends beyond the realm of engineering and commonly involves aspects of policy, social engineering, economics, etc.  Knowing how to combine and, equally important, keep together such disparate expertise can be a challenge in its own right.  Exploring and developing guidance on those issues and bringing together individuals with the mix of backgrounds and expertise required to tackle those problems were the primary goals of the workshop.

The workshop’s impact is likely to accrue over time as a result of the work it will, hopefully, help initiate, which should span both science and society.  Nevertheless, the workshop has already produced concrete and potentially impactful results. On the scientific front, it helped identify promising problems and challenges in both the sustainable computing and computing for sustainability areas. They are detailed in the workshop’s report that is publicly available through NSF and on the arXiv repository, and are outlined below.  Beyond the scientific realm, the workshop exposed close to 200 in-person and online attendees to approaches that can help successfully create and manage interdisciplinary teams, and, more importantly, the exchanges that took place between participants coming from a wide range of backgrounds and with very different perspectives were instrumental in formulating the workshop’s recommendations.

The workshop spanned close to two days and was held at the NSF facility in Arlington, VA.  It brought together 100 in-person attendees, with from 50 to 100 additional online (over zoom) participants.  They called from a broad range of disciplines (computer science, material science, social science, economy, etc.) and institutions (academia, industry, government, tier 1 research universities as well as teaching-focused colleges, science centers, etc.).  This ensured the necessary diversity of perspectives and skills required to foster productive conversations, and the breadth of impact (across disciplines and individuals) that the workshop sought to impart. The conversations that the workshop helped foster were organized in three highly interactive sessions (team science, sustainable computing, and computing for sustainability) that typically started with an information sharing phase, followed by open discussions, and concluding with a period focused on synthesizing recommendations.

The workshop’s main recommendations were organized in three areas. The first included broad recommendations that cut across the workshops two main themes of sustainable computing and computing for sustainability, while the latter two targeted recommendations specific to each one of those two themes. Those recommendations are summarized next with details available in the workshop’s report that is accessible at http://arxiv.org/abs/2407.06119.

General Recommendations

  1. Promote open data models and repositories that facilitate data sharing while preserving privacy, and equally important recognize that sustaining the operation of such repositories itself requires dedicated resources.

  2. Increase awareness of and accounting for the presence of human and social dimensions in most sustainability problems.

  3.  Sustainability is inherently interdisciplinary and developing effective solutions to sustainability problems requires establishing common languages and perspectives that transcend domain boundaries.

Sustainable Computing Recommendations

  1. Develop access to funding vehicles that acknowledge the interdisciplinary nature of sustainable computing research and facilitate bringing together the required expertise.

  2. Expand collaboration between industry and academia with a focus on technology transfer to increase the odds of impactful outcomes.

  3. Promote sustainable computing as a stand-alone topic on both the educational and research fronts.

Computing for Sustainability Recommendations

  1.  Expand climate models to better account for and incorporate local conditions and predict their impact.

  2.  Explore leveraging sustainable agriculture as a climate strategy.

  3.  Invest in harnessing machine learning for more efficient buildings.
